dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT -- station signboard. It reads:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS to show the dusty platform of a typical small Arizona town of the late nineties. CAMERA TRUCKS ALONG platform PAST a line of sleeping figu consisting of a couple of drunks, an Indian, two Mexicans and a mongrel dog. CAMERA STOPS on the window of the ticket office. Inside t office can be glimpsed the Station Agent dozing in a chai with his feet up against the grill of the ticket window. clicking of the signal indicator is heard. The agent open his eyes, flips up the indicator and begins to get to his feet sleepily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: line of sleeping figures, with dog in f.g. The sound of a distant train whistle is heard o.s. The dog, which up to might have been dead, opens one eye and looks past camera

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: railway track with the three-car train approaching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: line of sleeping figures. The dog jumps up barking furiou and runs out of shot past camera. The sleeping figures co to life and look toward camera. At the same time, the doo of the ticket office opens and the agent appears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: railway track. The train is now almost at the station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FULL SHOT -- with the line of men now standing on the edg of the platform looking toward camera. Train steams slowl in past camera, and stops, with a tall, wide-shouldered m of about 28 (Rocklin), dressed in new store clothes, cowb and a broad-brimmed white hat, in f. g. standing on steps day coach with a small valise and saddle in his hands. Be Rocklin a conductor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: baggage car. The baggageman is standing at the open door the car with two sacks of mail. He drops them to the plat and waves to the conductor o.s. and begins to close the d of the baggage car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: on Station Agent and conductors. The latter signals the  engineer. The train whistle sounds again o.s. and the sha of the moving train begins to pass across the Station Age face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Rocklin comes along the platform carrying the valise i one hand and balancing the saddle on his shoulder with th other, a man behind him picks up the two mail sacks and e from scene. The station bums look at Rocklin curiously. H expression giving no encouragement, they slink back out o the sun and begin to settle down in their old places agai At the ticket office, Rocklin pauses and looks around  uncertainly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at office door) Expectin' someone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a second's  pause) I guess not. Where's the stagecoach  office?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing) Back of the depot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The stage is drawn up in front of the depot, over which i sign --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: J. Harolday Proprietor

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin, making his way along the walk, almost reaches th depot when his attention is arrested by the sight of Dave the stage driver, who has just rounded in front of the le horses. He pauses close to one horse's head. Rocklin sees Dave take a bottle from his person, uncork it as he glanc around, and raise it to drink. The bottle is almost to Da lips when the horse shies, swinging its head. The bottle knocked from the old fellow's hands and smashes on the gr Now Rocklin witnesses a scene of intense fury, which he f amusing despite its seriousness. Old Dave rants and snort beats his thighs, his heads, flings his arms wildly and  exhibits his utter disgust generally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to horse) Consarn you, Blossom -- lookit that --  jus' lookit what you done -- (some more pantomime) I'm tellin' you, Blossom that -- (indicating broken  bottle) -- makes you the most aggravatin'  female as ever I had a despise fer --  I've got a good notion to pizen you --  an' what's more --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops talking abruptly because his hand has, quite by  chance, felt the spare bottle he carries, which he has  forgotten in his anger. A most satisfying smile lights hi bewhiskered face as he brings the bottle into view. He un it, and stepping a few paces from the horse, raises the  bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Blossom) Heh-heh -- fooled you, didn't I? -- (chuckles) Fooled myself, too.

dialogues.speaker: ON ROCKLIN
dialogues.text: who has been watching Dave's performance. He smiles his  amusement and now proceeds toward the stage office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAN SHOT. Rocklin enters and moves over to the counter, b which is the stage agent, a mild-looking man with pebble- lens glasses. During the scene, the character who picked the mail sacks from the platform, comes in, dumps the sac on the counter and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Rocklin) Howdy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating stage) That the stage for Santa Inez?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods) Leaving any minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin puts his saddle on the counter, and taking out a of bills, drops them on the counter. The Stage Agent coun out the fare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Santa Inez -- seventeen-fifty -- (returning the balance) Name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Stage Agent turns to make out the ticket. Rocklin tak some tobacco and paper from his vest pocket as he glances outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mind if I ride alongside the driver?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over his specs) It's all right with me -- if it's  all right with Dave -- He's mad --  His last trip -- Had a row with  Harolday, the boss -- Old-timer,  Dave -- an' a grumpy old cuss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (soberly) I like grumpy old cusses -- Hope to  live long enough to be one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puzzled) Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shakes his head and hands Rocklin the ticket, and move over to the door with one of the mail sacks in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Stage Agent, carrying a mail sack, and Rocklin come f the stage depot and reach the stage as Dave is in the act climbing up to the driver's seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's your mail, Dave --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave looks over his shoulder at the Agent and steps to th ground, as Rocklin climbs up to the driver's seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he steps up to  the seat) -- and a passenger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave glares at Rocklin climbing up to the seat, and he is about to order him down when Rocklin, now seated, looks d at him and asks rather wistfully --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mind if I ride up here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave does mind, but his better judgment tells him to step carefully in his attitude toward this stranger, who does  things first, then asks permission. His only answer to Ro is a characteristic grimace which is eloquent enough. And now Dave turns on the Agent, who becomes the target of hi pent-up wrath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's them wimmen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up at the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yanking mail sack  from Agent) Why ain't they here? -- This is the  stage depot, ain't it -- ? (heaves sack into  boot) Ain't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can pick 'em up there -- it's  only up the street --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On'y up the street -- an' they cain't  walk it -- What's the matter -- don't  Easterners have laigs like other  folks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave stalks around the rear of the coach. The Agent meant stretches himself up toward Rocklin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (so Dave won't hear) Hold tight when you git in the  mountains, mister -- When he gits  riled you can hear the passengers  prayin' for miles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave has climbed to his seat, and now the coach lurches a leaving the Agent shaking his head dubiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the porch of the hotel. We see the stage approaching the hotel handyman brings a trunk and a couple of bags fr the hotel to the street. The coach pulls up and stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to handyman) Whar's them wimmen? -- They waitin'  for you to carry 'em out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before the handyman can answer, Dave's attention is taken someone calling his name from across the street. Meantime an Indian squaw wobbles from the hotel with bow and arrow etc. Rocklin buys bow and arrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he comes to Dave) Dave -- Dave -- tell Arly Harolday  her saddle ain't ready yet, will ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting to the ground) I ain't tellin' that crazy female  nothin' -- Last time I seen her she  threatened to rip the hide off'n me  and bat me dizzy with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave goes to the rear of the coach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks up to Rocklin) Mister -- will you tell the Agent at  Santa Inez to tell Miss Harolday her  saddle ain't ready yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods) I'll say that.

dialogues.speaker: PORCH OF HOTEL
dialogues.text: Miss Martin steps out onto the porch followed by Clara an gentleman, presumably the hotel manager or clerk. The wom are obviously Easterners and are attired in the good tast of the period. Miss Martin is a domineering woman, approa middle age. Her niece, Clara, is a well-bred, attractive  girl of twenty-one and completely under the influence of older woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as group comes through  door) By next year, madam, we expect to  have a bathtub on each floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Martin stops short and looks o.s.

dialogues.speaker: ON DAVE AT REAR OF THE COUCH
dialogues.text: having a time lifting the trunk up into the boot. Miss Ma and the others come into the scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now don't drop it --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave pauses to see who is talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At your age you'd best not be lifting  things so heavy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grimaces) Mebbe you're young enough to hoist  her up your own self. (tries to lift trunk  again)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: on Clara. She is looking rather timidly up at Rocklin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: on Rocklin. He is grinning appreciatively at old Dave. No he notices Clara and regards her soberly a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave has heaved the trunk in place and is securing it. Miss Martin, about to enter the coach, notices Clara star up at Rocklin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clara!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clara snaps her attention from Rocklin to her aunt. The C steps to the side of the coach and opens the door. He ass Clara inside -- and now Miss Martin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Martin and Clara. Miss Martin is just sitting. She l coldly at Clara.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in low voice) Staring as though you'd never seen a  man before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave, Rocklin and Clerk. Dave is at the moment climbing t his seat on the other side of the coach. The Clerk swings the door closed and looks up to Rocklin and speaks more o less confidentially.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try to hold him down or he'll scare  the women to death.

dialogues.speaker: ON ROCKLIN
dialogues.text: He is looking down at the Clerk and answers quite casuall but loud enough to be heard by the women.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never feel sorry for anything that  happens to a woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THROUGH window of door -- Miss Martin and Clara. The wome have obviously overheard Rocklin's remark. Miss Martin sm vindictively at Clara, who flushes. CAMERA PULLS BACK to include the Clerk, who moves to the  coach door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I hope you have a nice trip,  ladies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope we get there -- wouldn't  surprise me if we didn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Dave and Rocklin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mutters) Wait till I get you on the road, you  old buzzard, you'll be surprised all  right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes up the reins and shouts the team away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXTREME LONG SHOT -- with the stage hardly more than a bl dot below, its curl of rising dust in the midst of the wh broad expanse. As the coach disappears from shot, the two mounted men appear riding at an easy pace and continue in the same direction as the coach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. CLOSE SHOT -- Dave and Rocklin, the latter staring  straight ahead. As they roll with the roll of the coach,  Dave steals a look at his companion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder why a young feller who don't  have to wants to come into this God  danged country?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin ignores Dave's question and continues staring ahe Dave glances down toward the women.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say -- did you mean what you said  back there about wimmen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grimly) Every word of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chuckling) Then you're smarter than most.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I seen more of 'em than most.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at him  admiringly) Shouldn't be surprised. Shouldn't be  a leetle bit surprised. (reflectively) All the same...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He breaks off and chuckles again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unsmilingly) All the same -- what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave doesn't reply, but lifting the pint of whiskey, jerk out the cork with one movement of his thumbnail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (offering bottle to  Rocklin) Take a slug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin drinks and gives the bottle back to Dave, who all but empties it in one pull.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding up the bottle  and squinting through  it) Whiskey and wimmen -- ever think how  much alike they are? Both fool you,  but you never figger out how to do  without 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin makes no reply. Dave offers the bottle again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not just yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unoffended) Well... (putting the bottle  to his lips) Here's to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The next one that fools you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He empties the bottle and shies it away. At the same time the coach hits a particularly bad patch of road and there muffled exclamation from inside the coach. Dave leans ove and looks down o.s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. CLOSE SHOT -- Clara and Miss Martin. The former is  showing the effects of the rough ride, but the old lady i hanging on grimly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave straightens up, grinning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with relish) Mighty rough stretch along here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He whips up the team, at the same time weaving a little  unsteadily in his seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like me to speel you a while?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope. I've had a few snorts but that  don't make no difference. Leas'ways,  never has... (after a second's  pause) Don't ever git wore out, and useless,  like me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who're them as say you are?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harolday, for one. Oh, I ain't belly- aching. Reckon he's entitled to his  opinion. But him and me never did  see eye to eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's constitootional, I reckon. Like  that step-daughter of his is crazy --  he's too sane. Believes In law and  order.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grinning) What's wrong with law and order?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Depends on who's a-dishin' it out.  Never was good at takin' orders  meself. As for the law -- well, you'll  soon find out what that means 'round  these parts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The coach hits a particularly bad bit of road and there i an exclamation from inside. Dave grins and urges the team cheerfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FULL SHOT -- as Dave pulls up the stage at the top of a l downgrade and looks out appreciatively at the view. From  this crest of the rim, a vast expanse of country is visib

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: stage. Miss Martin thrusts her head out of the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Driver? Driver, what's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothin'. Restin' hosses. Git out and  stretch yore laigs if you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Resting horses? What for? I can see  with my own eyes it's downhill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave brightens visibly at this challenge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You in such an all-fired hurry, lady?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly, we are in a hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beaming) Well -- we'll hurry some.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His whip cracks like a rifle shot and the startled horses literally jerk the heavy stage over the rim and down the  grade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: grade, with the stagecoach bounding and reeling down the  narrow road and around the sharp bends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave and Rocklin on stage as it thunders downhill. Dave i leaning out and listening hopefully for the outcries from within. None come. Rocklin is hanging on with both hands mildly amused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two women are really being scrambled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE TWO SHOT -- Dave and Rocklin. Rocklin is as calm as he were walking. Dave is more and more pleased with himse He again leans out to listen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: grade, with coach approaching in b.g. In f.g. the road na and makes a sharp turn at the very edge of a precipice. T is no possible way of getting the coach safely around thi turn except at a walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: road, from point of view of driver's seat, establishing t same menace ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave and Rocklin, as Rocklin glances out of the corner of his eyes as if wondering whether or not Dave is too drunk perceive the disaster. He makes no move, however, to advi or interfere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: road; at danger corner, as stage comes in. At the very la second, Dave pulls in the horses and negotiates the turn safety.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: stage. Dave grins at Rocklin, then listens for the outcry expects from the women within. The old lady's head bobs o of the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fiercely) Now what's the matter. Why are we  stopping again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old Dave's mouth drops open, and as Rocklin begins to gri at his discomfiture.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STAN'S PLACE
dialogues.text: FULL SHOT of lonely adobe which serves as a combination  roadhouse, stage station and bar. As the coach rolls into f.g., a little Mexican boy (Pablo) runs out to change the horses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as Rocklin swings  down) Buenas noches, senor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buenas noches, amigo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grinning at the  friendly tone) Ha llegado anticipademente, senor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tuvimos suerte en haber llegado.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He glances pointedly at Dave who is climbing down unstead and Pablo bursts out laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: on door of coach. As Dave comes into shot, Miss Martin's  head pops out of the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gruffly) We stop here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do we stop here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you wanta eat and stretch yore  laigs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you please stop referring to my  legs!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got some, ain't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and lurches toward the roadhouse.

dialogues.speaker: INT. STAN'S PLACE
dialogues.text: FULL SHOT from doorway. It is a large barn-like room on o side of which is a bar. On the other side is a fireplace a partition behind which is a rough dining table and benc Standing at the bar drinking with his back to the door is wizened little man, dressed in an odd assortment of ragge garments of unrecognizable origin. On the counter is a  travelling prospector's pack, to which is strapped an  assortment of prospector's equipment, including a pick an shovel. As Dave enters, the man (Zeke) turns around and  reveals a face even hairier than Dave's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding out his arms) Dave!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (letting out a yell  and rushing to Zeke) Why, Zeke, you two-legged old coot!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zeke and Dave as they beat one another on the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whar you been all these months?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up in the hills workin' my way down  the biggest hole you ever seed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good -- What's at the bottom of it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothin'!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (roaring with laughter) What, again!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin has entered and moved to the fire. Miss Martin an Clara enter and stand in the doorway watching the scene a the bar. A pale-faced, dyspeptic-looking man of about 45  (Stan) comes from the kitchen and approaches them  ingratiatingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening, ladies. How about  something to eat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a dubious look  toward the pair at  the bar) Well -- if it won't take too long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leading the way toward  the partition) This way, ladies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: bar. Dave has just fitted a cylindrical record of "She Wa Only a Bird in a Gilded Cage" to an old-type phonograph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep -- this is my last trip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old Harolday won't take back what he  said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd he say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "You're fired."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both yell with laughter and slap one another on the  back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: from fireplace. Rocklin is standing in f.g. looking down the fire and making the inevitable cigarette from his poc dip. Seated at the table are Clara and Miss Martin. From  o.s. comes the sound of Zeke and Dave singing to the  phonograph record. Miss Martin glares indignantly in the  direction of the bar, obviously about to make a protest. this moment Stan comes from the kitchen with a large dish his hand which he dumps on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There you are, folks. Dig in and  help y'rselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Martin, sitting forward eagerly, suddenly sees the d of meat and freezes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: dish of meat. It is swimming in greasy brown gravy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Martin as she shudders dyspeptically and closes her  eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: bar, as Stan comes from the table to Dave and Zeke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Supper, Dave?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (noisily) I'm drinkin' mine. Set 'em up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: table. Clara has filled a plate with food, which she offe to her aunt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Auntie --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With my dyspepsia? Do you want to  kill me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clara hesitates for a second, then looks across to Rockli

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you going to have any supper?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reckon so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He comes to table and begins to help himself. There is a  loud burst of laughter from the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young man, that driver's had all the  liquor he can take.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Has he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know he has. You're not a complete  fool, are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frequently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Clara, furiously) The rudeness of people in these parts  is appalling!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clara looks apologetically at Rocklin, then away again  nervously. Suddenly, she sees something o.s. and drops he knife and fork with a little start.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: window. A thin, unpleasant-looking face is seen through t glass. The windowpane is defective and so distorts the lo part of the face into a hideous smile. It is the younger the two men who were watching the coach outside the hotel

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: on kitchen door as Stan comes through with a dish of pota A man's voice is heard o.s. and he pulls up abruptly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, well -- smells like a mighty  nice bit of veal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA HAS PANNED TO include the side door next to the wi and almost opposite to the dining table. The owner of the face at the window (Bob Clews) is now standing in the doo Behind him is the man with the sheriff's badge on his dir vest (Jackson). As they come forward toward Stan, the lat shows obvious signs of nervousness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doin' yourself well these days, Stan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A friend of mine was by an' sold me  a quarter of beef.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (insinuatingly) The same friend as sold you that  hide Bob, here, found stashed in  your barn yesterday?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hide -- What hide?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The one that might send you to the  penitentiary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smugly) What did you do with it, Stan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never had no hide stashed --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (harshly) I saw it yesterday under the hay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then it must still be there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No it ain't -- we looked -- Where is  it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tell ya --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (who has been an  interested witness) What is all this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackson, as though noticing the women for the first time, raises his hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Afternoon ma'am. Miz Caldwell ain't  it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- Martin -- Miss Martin -- This  is Miss Caldwell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Clara) Glad to know you, miss -- Been  expectin' you at Santa Inez. I'm  Sheriff Jackson. Any relation of Red  Caldwell's a friend of mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (that oily smile) You're sure gonna brighten things up  considerable around the K.C. Ranch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Martin gives Clews an icy stare and snaps her eyes t Jackson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating Stan) What's going on with him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a little matter of the law.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hastily) Rustlin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wrestling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rustlin' -- cattle stealin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh -- a thief --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (visibly worried) I tell ya I never --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly) Save it --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Miss Martin) Matter of fact -- Bob, here, says  that the hide he saw yesterday had  the K.C. brand on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh -- hmmm -- well, what do you intend  doing about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at Stan) Law's pretty harsh 'round here on  cattle thieves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (being the kind man) Course, we don't want to make a  mistake with an old-timer, but --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin speaks from where he leans against the wall, casu smoking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about the owner of that beef --  mightn't he have somethin' to say  about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a pause in which all have turned their attention Rocklin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meanin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Red Caldwell -- he's the owner of  the K.C., ain't he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a short chuckle) You're 'way behind the herd, mister --  Red Caldwell died three weeks ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glaring at Clews) Was murdered, you mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right -- shot in the back --  not far from here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (significantly to  Stan) Maybe he was gettin' on to things  about the cattle that's been missin'  from the K.C. lately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tell ya I ain't never had any hide --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly) Well, you got beef --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (meekly defiant) Yes -- an' I got a bill of sale fer  it, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackson and Clews exchange a quick glance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: S'pose you let me see that bill of  sale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (starts for kitchen) It's right out here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackson follows, looking at the women.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like I said -- I wouldn't want to  make a mistake with an ole-timer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackson follows Stan into the kitchen. Clews moves to the fire and lunges there picking his teeth and eyeing Clara, who stirs uneasily under the man's gaze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Rocklin comes out of the thoughtful mood in which he h been plunged by the information about Red Caldwell and no the by-play between Clews and Clara. He frowns and makes movement as if about to rise. At the same time, Dave and  Zeke, whose voices have been heard throughout In the b.g. stagger into the shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chuckling and pointing  to Miss Martin) See that one? (confidentially) She ain't got no laigs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold your tongue. (to Zeke, who is gaping  at her) And you -- stop staring as if we  were monsters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zeke takes it and staggers into the b.g. near Bob Clews.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Rocklin) Where's Stan? We got to have another  drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's outside tryin' to explain away  a hide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating food) Seems we're eatin' stolen beef.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody's loco. Stan might have  given house-room to bit o' dead beef,  but he'd never be fool enough to  leave the hide lyin' around. (to Zeke) How 'bout it, Zeke?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zeke opens his mouth to speak, and slowly folds up, slidi down the wall to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Clews comes from the fireplace and joins the group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the way it is, Dave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave has gone to Zeke's aid and now peers at Clews closel recognizing him for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disgustedly) Oh -- it's you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right -- your old pal Bob  Clews.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shoves Clews) Git away from me -- you two-timin'  horse thief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grinning) Them's fightin' words, pardner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stan and Jackson come from the kitchen. Dave is again pic up Zeke, but seeing Stan, lets Zeke drop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (moving to Stan) Hey, Stan -- don't let 'em hang  nothin' on you, you ain't done.  They're just a couple of fourflushers --  the pair of 'em, everybody knows  that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackson addresses everyone present with an indulgent Smil

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crazy drunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wheels on Jackson) Mebbe I am drunk -- mebbe that's why  I'm tellin' the truth -- I'm drunk  an' I'll say what I think -- I'll  say what I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zeke, on the floor, takes up Dave's belligerent mood for flash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So will -- I -- (goes out again)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackson goes to Dave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't act up this ways, Dave -- They's  women watchin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clews moves in to Jackson and Dave, and now both men urge Dave toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (attempting to throw  them off) Git your hands off me --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to company in general) What he needs is a short lay-down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking a step forward) I'll lend a hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (brushing past him) Me an' Bob'll look after him. We're  his friends -- come on, Bob. (as they steer Dave  through door) Careful now -- don't hurt him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They exit. Rocklin stands frowning a second, then turns t the table where Stan is making a show of clearing dishes, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly to Stan) How are things standin' now between  you an' the law? (indicates direction  Jackson went out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not wanting to talk  about it particularly) All right, I reckon -- (looks at Rocklin;  more confidently) I guess this bill of sale -- (indicates it in Vest  pocket) -- kinda winded him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin's lips curl in a wise smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good thing you saved it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zeke is discovered on all fours crawling around on the fl near the table where the women sit. He seems to be lookin for something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mystified) What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zeke turns his hairy face up toward Miss Martin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Musta been dreamin' -- Thought I was  sittin' on a pot of gold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wearily) There ain't no gold here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (takes it) There ain't even a pot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door leading from the barn opens and Jackson enters  followed by Clews a few steps behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Went to sleep soon's we laid him  down. (pulling off hat again) Sorry to have a ruckus in front of  you ladies. Dave's an ornery old  cuss when he gets goin' -- No shape  to drive on, I'm afraid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (this is a fine kettle  of fish) Hmmm --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, ma'am. Bob, here, 'll  take you on in -- knows every inch  of the road -- Don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grins) You bet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin has been listening intently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm drivin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of the group, with Clews looking significantly at Jackson who is obviously checkmated by Rocklin's remark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (finally speaks) But if anything was to happen to the  ladies, I'd feel -- to blame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns abruptly and walks out the front door to the coa Jackson stares after him a moment, uncertain. Now he turn to the women.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ladies want he should drive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Martin hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be more'n glad to accommodate  you -- (smiles at Clara)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (resenting Clews'  familiarity) He's going with us anyway -- he may  as well drive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything you say, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STAN'S PLACE
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT -- coach as Rocklin moves toward it from the ho A crudely made arrow shoots in and hits Rocklin lightly. warning hiss is heard o.s. and he turns quickly in the  direction of the sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT -- door of stable. The little Mexican who atten the horses is peering out from the stable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a whisper) Venga con migo, senor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kid disappears inside the stable. Rocklin comes into  shot from the direction of the coach and enters the stabl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin comes through the door and moves toward the boy, is standing looking downward into some hay. CAMERA PANS DOWN to show Dave unconscious, with a nasty c in his scalp. Rocklin kneels into the shot. Over the scen comes the sound of retreating hoofbeats.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STAN'S PLACE
dialogues.text: LONG SHOT -- from Rocklin's ANGLE in the stable, of Jacks and Bob Clews riding away. INT. STABLE - STAN'S PLACE - LATE AFTERNOON SHOT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to boy) Did they do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods) Si, senor. They hit him with a  pistola.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (matters) His friends, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He kneels again, picks Dave up, and prepares to carry him out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LONG SHOT of stagecoach traveling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin on the driver's seat, handling the reins expertly

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PANNING SHOT -- with Miss Martin and Clara now seated nex to one another. Clara is half asleep with her head agains the side of the coach. Miss Martin is sitting bolt uprigh but her eyes are closed and her head nods. CAMERA PANS to include the other side of the coach where Dave is sprawle in the seat, his head on a cushion, his mouth open, sound asleep. Suddenly he snores violently, and Miss Martin wak with a start and glares at him angrily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PANNING SHOT on sign on window which reads: RED ROCK STAGE SANTA INEZ DEPOT Proprietor -- J. Harolday

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS to show the coach pulled up outside, with Roc lifting his saddle from the top of the coach, whilst a  stableman holds up Dave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bumped his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (skeptically) Where -- on Iron Mountain?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's the best chance of a cheap  room?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing) There's Cap's place across the Street --  the Sun-Up Saloon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with valise, indicates  saddle) I'll pick that up later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: group, to include the window of the coach. Miss Martin's  head appears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to stableman) This isn't the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No'm, lady. Hotel's up the street a  piece.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are we expected to carry our bags at  this time of night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Rocklin) Want to drive 'em on up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flatly) Nope. (offering a shoulder  to Dave) Here -- catch aholt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two move out of shot across the road, followed by the indignant gaze of Miss Martin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PANNING SHOT -- opening on the sign over the door, which  reads:

dialogues.speaker: SUN-UP SALOON
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS to show Rocklin and Dave coming along the  boardwalk in front of the saloon. CAMERA PANS them to the swing-doors, which Rocklin pushes open, passing through i the saloon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PANNING SHOT -- SHOOTING FROM BEHIND the bar toward the s doors as Dave and Rocklin enter. The bartender (Cap), a l tallish man of about 50, studies them as they enter, then turns and calls across the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Doc!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS to show a group of poker players seated aroun table. This consists of a well-dressed, powerful-looking of about 45 (Judge Garvey), with a smooth face and an  impressive manner; a flashily-dressed young man with a we face (Clint Harolday); a tough-looking cowboy of about 35 (Ab Jenkins); a pleasant-faced storekeeper of about 50 (P Fossler); and a little man with a weather-beaten face and intensely blue eyes (Doc Riding). Watching the game are S Haynes and Shorty Davis, the former a townsman and the la a cowboy. As they all look toward the door, Cap's voice  continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Customer --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc Riding looks quickly toward the door, taking in the  situation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Haynes) Take my hand, Sammy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin and Dave come to the bar. At the same time, Doc R comes into shot from the poker table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bumped his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dryly) I see. (examining the head) Looks like he's going to need a couple  or so stitches. (to Cap) Better get him upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bartender looks dubious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding) Okay. You can book me a room, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Rocklin and Doc Riding begin to lead Dave toward the  Stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUCKING SHOT -- starting on big head of Dave, as he lies bed, with his eyes closed. His head is swathed in a clean bandage. He stirs and gives a little chuckle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (muttering) No laigs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PULLS BACK to show Doc Riding at the bed and Rockl beyond, standing in the connecting doorway between two  bedrooms. The latter has a face towel in his hands and ha evidently been washing up. As Dave settles down comfortab in the bed, Doc Riding closes his bag, nods to Rocklin an moves toward the second bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. CLOSE SHOT -- as Doc Riding comes through the doorwa from Dave's room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll be all right in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin closes door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about a snort?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't mind if I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves across the room, followed by Rocklin, who throws the towel down on the bed as he passes. For a second, he  hesitates as if about to pick up the gun-belt which is ly on the bed. Then, deciding to leave it, he follows the do through the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. CLOSE SHOT -- at bar, with Cap Setting up glasses fo Doc Riding and Rocklin. He nods to indicate the bedroom  upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a grin) Will he make it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure he'll make it. Can't kill off a  salty old hairpin like Dave that  easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right. Reckon Saint Peter  must be gitten' mighty tired of  dustin' off that doormat for him. (to Rocklin) By the way, how did you say it  happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stolidly) I didn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a slight nod of  approval) That's right; you didn't. (casually) Reason I ask is, a couple fellers  was in saying how Dave was kickin'  up a ruckus up at Stan's place. (to Doc Riding) Sheriff Jackson it was and one of  the Clewses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a look of  distaste) Oh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cap reverts to Rocklin, still casually, but with an under of friendly warning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tough customers, the Clewses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah -- don't pay to start something  with 'em you don't intend to finish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Doc Riding before  Rocklin can answer) By the way, Doc, they tell me  George'll be out again. (to Rocklin, with the  same casual air) That's Bob Clews' brother. Jest done  a stretch in pen 'tentiary for horse  stealin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They string 'em up for that where I  come from.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (muttering into his  drink) Pity they didn't string him up while  they wore about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what Arly Harolday was sayin'  only this mornin'. (to Rocklin) You ain't met our Arly yet, I reckon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He will, if he stays here long enough. (chuckles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell-fire in skirts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (raises his glass;  grinning) Well, here's now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They down the drinks. There is a burst of excited comment from o.s. and they all look around toward the poker table

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poker table from bar. The flashily-dressed youngster is r in the stakes triumphantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did I tell you? They gotta be  big to beat me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Group at bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clint Harolday's in luck tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're certainly running for him.  About time, too. He's taken a beating  this last week would shake a better  man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poker table and including bar. Sammy Haynes has risen and pushing back his chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Include me out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw -- come on. Can't you take it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not that sort o' luck, I can't.  Besides, I on'y came in to oblige.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning to bar and  shouting) Come on, Doc. I still got to take  something from you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) No more tonight, son. I've a full  day ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judge Garvey in foreground has been watching Rocklin, as trying to sum him up. He now leans forward with an  ingratiating smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about you, sir? Care to sit In?  I'm warnin' you, though -- our young  friend here has been holding  phenomenal cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin smiles and begins to shake his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a cocky grin) Have a heart, Judge. This ain't no  two-bit saddle-tramp's game. This is  for real money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin turns very slowly and stares at Clint. The others watch curiously. Without taking his eyes off Clint, he co forward slowly and stands looking down at him. Then,  unbuttoning the flap of his pocket, he takes out the wad bills and drops it on the table, at the same time sinking into the chair vacated by Sammy. The tension amongst the  onlookers relaxes and Clint grins at Garvey and winks  significantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine! Oh -- this is Pap Fossler;  Shorty Davis; Ab Jenkins; Mr.  Harolday, and my name's Garvey --  Judge Garvey. I didn't get your name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't give it. (to Pap, who is holding  the cards) Deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT -- poker table, including Cap, who is watching. Pap Fossler is dealing. There is an atmosphere of tension around the table, and it is obvious that Clint has been  losing. As he picks up his cards, he is unable to restrai smile of triumph. Rocklin makes a bet. Pap Fossler and th man next to him fold immediately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raise you twenty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is more than Rocklin has in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) Table stakes, Clint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not if he wants to dig.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stares challengingly at Rocklin. Rocklin takes out a  wallet, from which he removes a bill and sees the raise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (folding) No place for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cards?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eagerly) One for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches for it almost before it is dealt and as a resu the card, a Queen, falls face up. Clint looks at it gleef snatches it up and puts it in his hand. Rocklin watches h impassively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you know that Queen is dead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can take it if I want it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure -- if you want -- but you'll  have to beat my hand with four cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hotly) I'm playing these, mister!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin glances inquiringly at the other players. All are dead-panned, unwilling to interfere. Rocklin looks toward Cap, who stands near him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) I'm not settin' in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smoothly) Why don't you split the pot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not splitting -- I'm betting!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shoves all the money in front of him into the pot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you calling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calmly) No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clint excitedly starts to rake in the pot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm raising.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shoves in the money in front of him, which is more tha Clint's and in addition takes from his wallet more bills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dig.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clint, very excited, empties his pockets, which is not en

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to other players) Let me have some money

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (speaking for all) You're in deep enough, Clint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disgusted, to Rocklin) I've called for all I've got. (spreads out his cards) Full house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No good. (spreads his hand) Kings up. Your third queen is dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin starts raking in the pot. Clint, almost hysterica jumps up, draws his gun and thrusts it almost into Rockli face. The other players roll away from the line of fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (screaming) You -- mister -- get away from that  table. And get out of here. Maybe  from now on you'll know a full house  beats two pairs -- four-flusher!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin, his hands outspread, slowly straightens up, rise and backs away. At the foot of the stairs, he turns  deliberately and walks upstairs. When he disappears from  view --

dialogues.speaker: CLINT
dialogues.text: Clint breaks the tension, looking from one to the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No man can run a bluff on me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a cold silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (finally) He wasn't armed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like to tell men how to play  cards unless I'm settin' in -- but I  mebbe ought to have spoken up. (directly to Clint) That Queen was dead, Clint -- and  you know it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (arrogantly) When anybody plays poker with me,  they play my game or not at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't just go makin' your own  rules, Clint -- (starts for the bar --  stops and turns) -- an' if I was you I'd hightail  outa here before he comes back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (jolted) Comes back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wearily) He's the kind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cap turns and resumes his trek to the bar. Suddenly he st before reaching it and is looking up, o.s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin is standing there grimly surveying the situation. he starts down the stairs...

dialogues.speaker: THE GROUP AROUND THE POKER TABLE
dialogues.text: They are staring o.s. Clint is very uneasy. And now Rockl moves slowly into the scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with deadly calm) I've come for my money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nervously pleasant) It's all yours, mister -- Cap, there --  Cap is an old gambler -- he says you  were right all the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clint again looks around for approval, but gets no respon Rocklin comes slowly forward, picks up the money from the table and turns back to the stairs. As he reaches the foo of the stairs, he turns and looks straight at Garvey with peculiar expression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the way, Judge -- the name is  Rocklin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUCKING SHOT -- on a small cracked mirror in which can b seen the reflection of a man shaving. A voice is heard  singing, atrociously off key.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was only a bird in a gilded  cage... (etc.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PULLS BACK to show that the owner of tie voice is  Rocklin, who has almost finished shaving. As he scrapes h chin and whistles, peering at himself in the little crack mirror, he hears the sound of the door opening and turns, then ducks quickly as a boot flies past him, just missing the mirror. There is the sound of the door slamming and  Rocklin grins. He picks up the boot and goes to the door  leading to Dave's room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Rocklin enters, Dave is discovered almost dressed sitt on the bed. Rocklin, glad to see him, smiles and tosses t boot to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How you feelin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After that singin'? -- Thirsty. (pulls on his boot)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's your head?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (evidently not aware  of what happened) Oh -- a mite hungover -- but I'll  feel better once I git downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hurries out the hall door. Rocklin, amused at the old  coot, starts back into his room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin is just coming through the door and sees somethin o.s., stops and freezes. CAMERA PULLS BACK to include Bob Clews leaning against th open ball door leading into Rocklin's room. He smiles as  Rocklin sees him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knocked, but guess you didn't hear  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (closing door to Dave's  room) What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grinning) Looks like you stirred things up  around here last night, stranger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That all you came to say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I got a message for you. (getting no response) From Old Man Harolday. Wants to see  you out front.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe he wants to thank you for  teaching that pup of his a lesson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a second) I'll be down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clews hesitates for a second as if anxious to wake sure h is coming, then, turning, he disappears into the hall. Ro wipes the last of the lather off his chin, buckles on his gun-belt and picking up his hat goes out, closing the doo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT -- Dave, at the bar, grabbing a bottle, pours  himself a drink which he sinks in one draught. He shudder and repeats the dose. During this, an excited murmur of v has been heard o.s. Dave turns and looks toward the far s of the saloon and suddenly gapes.

dialogues.speaker: FROM THE BAR
dialogues.text: with Dave in f.g., and SHOOTING TOWARD the street. A grou of men, including Cap, the bartender, is gathered round t window looking out into the street. Dave staggers across them and begins to push his way to the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: group at window as Dave pushes them aside to get a view o what is happening outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's goin' on here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arly Harolday's on the warpath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PANNING SHOT -- including Arly and Juan mounted in front the stagecoach office, which is situated diagonally acros the street from the Sun-Up. CAMERA HOLDS ON one group standing in front of Pap Fossle store, opposite the Sun-Up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here he comes. Watch the fun. This  should be good. Etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON the window. The men inside, including Dave and Cap, ar pressed against the glass. CAMERA MOVES BACK and PANS TO the alleyway at the side of the saloon. Rocklin is coming toward the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin, as he comes out of the shadow of the alleyway an stands blinking in the full sunlight. Sensing something  unusual, he looks quickly around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: from Rocklin's ANGLE. CAMERA PANS OVER the groups in the  street, STOPPING ON one which includes Bob Clews. As Clew sees Rocklin, he nudges a bystander and looks toward the  stagecoach office with a grin. CAMERA PANS to include Arly and Juan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin as he takes in the situation. With a grim look, h begins to move along the sidewalk, CAMERA TRUCKING WITH h Suddenly, there is the clatter of a horse's hooves and Ar gallops into shot, forcing the mare up onto the sidewalk barring Rocklin's progress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (imperiously) Is your name Rocklin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coldly) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (contemptuously) I want that money you took from my  brother last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) Are you crazy? Or just ignorant?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flaming) You took it at the point of a gun -- (suddenly whipping a  revolver from her  saddle holster) -- and I'm taking it back the same  way!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of group at window of Sun-Up Saloon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of group including Bob Clews, as Clint Harolday rides in stares o.s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin, as he looks coldly from Arly to the run and back again. Calmly taking the reins, he forces the mare's head and moves on. Furiously, Arly spurs the mare alongside, C TRUCKING WITH them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (furiously) Stop! You! stop, or I'll kill you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arly and Rocklin. Rocklin continues along the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pulls up her horse) Turn around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arly. She raises her gun.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKLIN CONTINUES WALKING
dialogues.text: A shot comes from o.s. and strikes the building close to  him. He stiffens but keeps on walking. Another shot comes even closer this time. He keeps walking.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKLIN HAS REACHED THE SWINGING DOORS OF THE SUN-UP
dialogues.text: As he puts out his hand to push open the door,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin's hand on the door as four shots in quick success spatter a line down the door close to his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUCKING SHOT -- Rocklin, as he continues his forward mov through the swing-doors. CAMERA PULLS BACK in front of hi into the saloon until it reaches the bar. Cap moves from  window with crowd and goes behind bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whiskey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT -- Arley with the smoking gun still in her han She stares wildly after Rocklin for a second, then wheels her horse violently toward the group which includes Cling Harolday and Bob Clews.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: group surrounding Clews and Clint Harolday. The clatter o hoofs is heard and Arly gallops furiously into shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You lied to me, didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't think I'll forget this. Making  a fool of me in front of the whole  town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before Clint can reply, she wheels the mare and gallops o of shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT -- as the customers, with Dave in f.g., mill ar Rocklin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, oh boy, was that a near thing!  She'd just as soon have hit you as  missed. You don't know how lucky you  were, son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't I? (indicating whiskey  with a sickly grin) Why d'you think I need this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sinks the whiskey and begins to pour himself another. the same time, the swing-doors open and Bob Clews comes  through. AS Rocklin raises the glass to his lips, Bob Cle hits him on the back, causing him to spill the whisky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Funniest sight I ever seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a moment's pause. Then with a slow, grim smile o satisfaction, Rocklin turns and knocks Bob Clews off his  feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: with Bob Clews on the floor, tugging at his gun. As it co free of the holster, Rocklin brings his heel down on Clew wrist, grinding on it with his whole weights. Then, kicki the gun out of reach, Rocklin steps back. Bob Clews sits clutching his wrist and weaving back and forth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (moaning) You broke it! You broke it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try another trick like that on me  and it'll be worse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never played you no trick. You  broke my wrist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: to include the bystanders. They look at Bob Clews without sympathy. He gets to his feet and stumbles back, collapsi in a chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: at bar, Dave has taken the bottle from Cap and is refilli Rocklin's and his own glass ecstatically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gurgling with delight) Oh boy -- has somebody come to town!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sinks both drinks quickly and is about to refill them  when Cap takes the bottle from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Cap) Where'll I find Judge Garvey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rooms behind his office down the  street. Don't usually pull up the  blinds till around noon, though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (putting down money) He will this morning. (to Dave) See you later, old-timer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he moves toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clint Harolday is seen at the window peering furtively to the Sun-Up Saloon. He suddenly notices something o.s. whi prompts him to say something which we of course cannot he Now Garvey appears at the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin, FROM Garvey's ANGLE as he leaves the Sun-Up and  starts toward the Judge's office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Garvey and Clint, at the window. From their expressions i is apparent that anxious words are passing between them, now Clint suddenly drops from sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON Arly and Juan, mounted. They see Rocklin going into  Garvey's place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT -- TOWARD door, with Garvey at desk in f.g. The door opens and Rocklin enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (effusively) Oh, come in, Mr. Rocklin. Come right  in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin looks him over for a second, then comes quietly t the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand you were Red Caldwell's  lawyer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (immediately on guard) I was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Know anything about this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes out a letter and hands it to Garvey. The latter  takes it slowly, handling it as if it were dangerous. He  looks from the letter to Rocklin and back again. Then  reluctantly, he opens it and begins to read. LETTER -- It reads: Dear Mr. Rocklin: Glad you have made up your mind to take the job. Enclosed find train fare and $150 advance on wages. Yours faithfully, J. Caldwell

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin and Garvey. The latter looks up from the letter  completely bewildered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand. Job? What job?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Foreman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gaping) On the "K.C."? (trying to take it in) But -- but why should he want you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? Good foremen don't grow on  bushes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a little pause, with Garvey still bewildered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thinking hard) Is that your only motive for coming  here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What other motive could I have?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know -- It's just that Red  Caldwell was a peculiar man -- had a  funny way of doing things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He studies Rocklin a short moment, then sits back comfort and relieved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm sorry, Mr. Rocklin, that  you've been brought all this way on  a fool's errand, but -- I'm afraid  the deal's off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Off?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to be too hard on you,  but as executor of the estate I have  to consider the interests of the new  owner. How about, say, a hundred in  full settlement?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thoughtfully) Well --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a knock on the door. Garvey rises and speaks on way to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's my last word -- think it over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Garvey opens the door, and Miss Martin stalks in followed Clare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (graciously) How do you do, ladies --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (icily) You are Judge Garvey, I presume.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods) Yes -- and you are --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Martin -- and my niece, Clara  Caldwell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reaching for a chair) Of course -- of course --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Martin sits stiffly as she eyes Rocklin coldly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You came at a very opportune moment,  madam. This gentleman claims to have  some sort of a letter from the late  Mr. Caldwell, engaging him as foreman  of the "K.C."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Garvey) What do you mean -- claims to have? --  You saw it, didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (before Garvey can  answer) You can't hold us to account for  every promise made by that man.  Everyone knows he wasn't responsible  for his actions half the time. And  if you think I'd have you as a foreman --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (finds it hard to  control himself) Listen, lady -- I'd rather walk for  somebody else, than ride for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taken aback) Well -- the impudence --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I come for this morning was to  pay beck the hundred and fifty Red  Caldwell sent in advance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all turn and stare at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't interfere, Clara. Of course he  must pay it back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The railway fare -- well, I reckon  we can check that up against the  time lost and call it quits. (throws down a roll  of bills in front of  Garvey)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (summoning up her  courage) But, Mr. -- er -- I don't know your  name...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (raising his hat) Rocklin, miss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Rocklin, it isn't fair for you  to pay anything back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's how I'd prefer it, If you  don't mind, miss -- never did care  fer owing favors to no one --  especially women.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as if she had been  struck) Oh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sound of rapid steps approaching from outside is hear and they all look toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: on door, as it opens to admit Arly. Ignoring everyone in room except Garvey, she comes abruptly to the desk, with riding quirt dangling from her wrist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've just heard they let George Clews  out of penitentiary and that he's  headed this way. You might tell him  from me, if he sets foot on the Santee  Ranch, I'll shoot him on sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But really, Miss Arly, why should  you deliver your message through me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have mutual friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're referring to Sheriff  Jackson...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But that's absurd. The fact that he  employs one of the Clews brothers  doesn't make the other his friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (contemptuously) Have it your own way; but it'd be  fair to warn him, because I mean it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the first time, she appears to be conscious of the  presence of the other women.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hastening to change  the conversation) Oh, Miss Caldwell, this is Miss  Harolday -- Miss Martin, Miss  Caldwell's aunt. You should know one  another, seeing you'll be neighbors.  Miss Harolday runs the Santee Ranch  for her stepfather. She's a famous --  ah -- horsewoman in these parts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with ingenuous  enthusiasm) I know. I saw you ride into town  this morning. You looked lovely.  Just what I'd like to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arly stares at her unbelievingly for a second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slowly, a bit  flustered) Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks slowly from Clara to Rocklin, as if suspecting  collusion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (completely innocent) Oh, this is Mr. Rocklin. He drove us  in from Garden City last night. He...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dead pan) I already met Miss Harolday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stonily, to Rocklin) I've a message for you -- from  Harolday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (murmuring) What, again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wants you to come down to the  office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's got a proposition to make --  about riding for him. Sixty a month.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmmm -- That's a foreman's wages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly exploding) I wouldn't offer you a red cent. (controlling herself) But it's his money. (bitingly) And the way things are shaping, maybe  we could do with somebody as mean as  you around the ranch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pushing her way  forward) I warn you, you're making a great  mistake. This man is no good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Auntie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Rocklin ignoring  Miss Martin) Well? D'you want the job?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin, as he stares at Arly with an enigmatic expressio Suddenly, he seems to make up his mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating the door) Lead the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Arly turns abruptly on her heel and exits the way she  came. Rocklin makes a little gesture to the ladies with h hat and follows. As he goes, Juan, who has been leaning  against the doorpost, follows, closing the door behind hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after they have gone) Auntie, why did you have to say that?  I simply don't understand you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cutting in, grimly) But I understand you. (scathingly) I'd be ashamed of myself. Throwing  myself at a man like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... I... (suddenly bursting  into tears) Oh, you're horrid -- horrid. I wish  I'd never come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns abruptly and drops onto the couch by the window CAMERA PANS TO HOLD A CLOSE TWO SHOT of Garvey and Miss  Martin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must excuse her. She's young.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And inexperienced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Garvey leans back in his chair and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (significantly) And young people must be protected  from themselves at times -- don't  you agree?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Martin throws him a quick look, which he returns  steadily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at last, with a grim  echo of a smile) Exactly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arly and Rocklin walking along the street, not far from  Harolday's office. Rocklin glances back toward Julio, who following a few paces behind them. He rides his horse and leading Arly's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Arly, indicating  Julio) Does he always follow you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (defiantly) He's not following me -- he's with  me -- he's always with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (takes it mildly) Oh -- just an old Indian friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (straight at him) The best friend I've got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin nods, looks back again at Julio, then back to Arl as they go out of shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAINING SHOT -- as Arly comes to from the street, followe by Julio and Rocklin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (abruptly to Rocklin) Wait here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS her over to a door marked "PRIVATE," which sh opens without knocking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
