dialogues.text: MED. SHOT as Arly comes through from the outer office tow Harolday, who is seated at desk in f.g. At Arly's abrupt  entrance, he looks up, startled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've just hired a man named Rocklin  and said you made me do it. Sixty  dollars and he 'll earn it -- while  he lasts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a little pause. Harolday's face is completely de pan. He looks out of the window for a second, then back a Arly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) Why did you do it, Arly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I can fire him. I hate him. Clint  and he quarrelled last night. Clint  lied about it and I made a fool of  myself. (nodding toward the  outer office) He's outside now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a little sigh) All right. Send him in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arly goes to the door and opens it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling) Come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin comes in and Arly exits without a word, closing t door behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Rocklin comes from the doorway into f.g. of shot, faci Harolday, who is seated on the far side of the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Rocklin, what happened between  you and my son last night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmmm. About this suggestion of you  working for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's your suggestion, not mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ye-es. Sixty dollars is big money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning to go) If you've changed your mind...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no.... Wait a minute. I take it  you've had the experience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enough for Red Caldwell to hire me  as foreman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh -- had Caldwell hired you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah -- but I won't ride for the new  owners -- so that leaves me open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see -- Were you a friend of Red's?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- I guess he just heard about  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sudden clatter of feet is heard and all eyes turn towar the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Dave, followed by Arly and Juan, bursts in. His eyes g around the room quickly until he finds Rocklin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as excited as a  schoolboy) George Clews is in town. He's seen  what you done to Bob and he's a- lookin' for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all look quickly toward the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LONG SHOT -- from stagecoach office window. The center of the street is clear and men's heads are peering from door

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT -- group at window, looking into street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The street is clear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave turns and looks curiously at Rocklin, who frowns  impatiently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Dave irritably) Tell him I'll be out in the street  in front of the saloon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dashing out, radiant) Uh-huh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is quite full and the atmosphere is one of  expectancy despite the outward casualness of the patrons. group lolls near the window, looking toward the stage off At the door a couple of customers peer out over the swing doors. The bar supports other customers engaged in variou private conversations but all are mindful of the presence George Clews who, with his brother, Bob, stands at the ba center, morosely toying with a glass of whisky in front o him. He is quite conscious of the subtle glances of the  others, but regards them all with disdain. He downs his d and speaks his thought to Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna get his ears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly Old Dave appears in a high state of excitement, halts with the swinging doors half open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (loudly) Hi you, George Clews --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George Clews turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin says if you don't come out,  he'll come in here after you, an'  tear you apart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George Clews frowns. His eye catches sight of a king-size glass of beer being slid across the bar to Shorty Davis,  standing alongside him. That quick, Clews beats Shorty to the glass and hurls it at Dave, who ducks out. Cap,  anticipating trouble, brings a sawed-off shotgun up from  under the bar and now watches Clews and Shorty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taps Clews) That was my beer, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nastily) If he comes in again -- I'll throw  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before Shorty can reply, Clews yanks his hat down over th little fellow's eyes, and gives him a backward shove that sends him sprawling into a corner where we leave him  struggling to get his hat off. The crowd resents this, bu doesn't dare do anything, except Cap, who holds his shotg in sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the Clews) That does it, boys -- you know where  the door is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Bob) Com-mon -- I'll get his ears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not until I get my money --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George and Bob Clews are now a few steps from the bar. Th have turned as Cap spoke and are looking at the shotgun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's three drinks and a broken  beer glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Bob, after a  second's deliberation) Pay 'im.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George turns and starts for the doors as Bob comes back t the bar to settle up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get his ears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) That Rocklin'll kill him for sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Le's hope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As George Clews steps outside, a mangy mongrel dog, baski close by, evidently recognizes him and tails it away, lea George blinking at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin -- FROM George's ANGLE. He is walking slowly forw down the middle of the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George, looking baffled by the steady approach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling) I'm coming -- and you'd better run!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He steps down from the sidewalk into the street and then  stands still again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin -- CAMERA MOVING WITH him as he comes slowly and  steadily forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George. His hands are on his guns, but drunk or not, he h too much sense to draw too soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT -- Harolday watching from behind the window of office. Behind Harolday are Julio and Arly. The latter ma a step as if about to move to the door, but Julio restrai her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. CLOSE SHOT -- as Garvey, Miss Martin and Clara watch the scene below -- Garvey and Miss Martin excitedly and C in great distress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSER SHOT -- men in hotel doorway, taut with excitement

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin -- SHOOTING PAST George, whose hands are on his g butts. Rocklin's thumbs are hooked in his belt as he cont slowly forward, his eyes fixed on George's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) Draw a gun and I'll kill you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George, as he stands bewildered and open- mouthed. Rockli enters scene, suddenly whips out his gun and brings it  crashing down alongside George's head. The barrel strikes though the crown of his hat and he goes down like a pole- axed steer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. CLOSE SHOT -- group at window. Arly gives an involun exclamation of pleasure, which she instantly checks, then she moves abruptly out of shot, followed by Juan. Harolda continues to stare frowningly out of the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. CLOSE SHOT -- group at window, with Garvey obviously disapponted, Miss Martin bridling and Clara showing obvio relief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT -- Rocklin and crowd as they swirl around him  offering congratulations. Dave pushes his way through the crowd and thumps Rocklin on the back in wild enthusiasm. the same time, the sound of a horse cantering is heard, a Jackson comes into shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Rocklin) Hey, you! What's this you been up  to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just laid a gun barrel over the  head of a drunk friend of yours --  same as you did over Dave's here  yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised) Eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (blustering) I don't know what you're talking  about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calmly) You're a liar!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns contemptuously and begins to move back towards t stage office completely ignoring Jackson, who rides along blusteringly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you lookee here, young feller.  You go on talking that way and you'll  find yourself in trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd which has been following now begins to razz him openly. He turns and glares, but without effect. He gives final shout to Rocklin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't say you ain't been warned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pulling his horse around, he sets off in a lope up the st

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Miss Martin comes along the street, determinedly, foll by Clara, until she is face to face with Rocklin outside stage office where Arly and Juan are mounted ready to mov off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ignoring everyone  but Rocklin) I saw you. I saw you strike that  poor man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am. As hard as I could.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ruffian, you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clara pulls her sleeve imploringly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me go! (to Rocklin) I knew the sort you were the moment  I set eyes on you. You can't fool  me! You're nothing but a common  adventurer! Come, Clara!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes Clara by the arm and sweeps past them towards t hotel. Rocklin looks after them with a grim expression an then up at Arly, who has been listening intently. She ret his look steadily for a second. Then, with a mocking smil she wheels the mare and canters out of shot, followed by  Juan. He looks after her for a second; then with the same grim look, enters Harolday's office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harolday is standing at the window, looking toward the do having seen Rocklin approaching. The door opens and Rockl enters and resumes his conversation as though it were har interrupted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Now what was that you were sayin'  about Caldwell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You being hired by Red Caldwell only  confirms what I'd suspected -- he  was getting ready to fight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to get  information) Fight? Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Organized rustling. Well at least --  that's my belief. Red was no friend  of mine. Too fond of taking the law  into his own hands. But he had my  sympathy. He'd been harder hit than  any of us. And on top of it all, he  lost his foreman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean, he quit on him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was shot -- in the back -- with a  bullet from the same caliber rifle  as got Red.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got any ideas?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- Except that the man you just  pistol-whipped is in on it somewhere. (bitterly) Pity you didn't kill him when you  had the chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin realizes that maybe Harolday is trying to throw a curve -- trying to get him to talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say -- it don't sound as if it's  goin' to be too easy for them wimmen  at the K.C.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (watching him keenly) Want to go back and work for them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir. And I ain't jumping at this  offer o' yours either because I don't  hold with working for wimmen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly) Oh, you mean my step-daughter. Well  don't worry. She won't interfere  with you...Rocklin -- I figure we've  been losin' cattle over a place called  Table Top -- it's the back way into  the Topaz Ranch and the perfect route  for rustlers -- I'm going to send  you up to the line camp -- you don't  mind working a lone hand -- do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (measuring) -- I like workin' that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising and holding  out a hand) Good -- be ready to move out this  afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Dave and Pap Fossler engaged in conversation in front Pap's store. In the b.g. -- across the street, we carry t entrance to the Sun-Up Saloon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in his best sales  talk) -- now Pap -- I'm givin' you first  call on me services. They's lots of  other folks lookin' fer a good man,  too -- you know. So if you want me,  you better hurry and speak up because --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During Dave's speech Rocklin has come from the Sun-up car his valise. He pauses a moment, looking around. Dave sees him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'scuse me, Pap -- Be right back to  find out when I start.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hurries across the street toward Rocklin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Rocklin just stepping off the curb. Dave comes in to h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whar you off to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm riding for the Topaz Ranch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They start across the street, slowly toward the stage off

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What! -- Have you gone plumb loco?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good money -- sixty a month

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There ain't enough money in this  town to make it worth your while to  work for that gal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin gives Dave a quizzical look, which Dave mistakes weakening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When she gits goin' she can be  meaner'n a skillet full o' snakes.  She ain't goin' to forget the way  you made a fool of her today -- in  front of the whole town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Dave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be right with you. (to Rocklin) It's pizen that's what it is -- jus'  plain --- What you want to hang around  this town for anyways? --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave and Rocklin have reached middle of the street. Pap  Fossler's voice comes again from o.s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Dave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave reacts with a squint in Pap's direction. He runs out toward Pap, but would rather stay with Rocklin. THE CAMER FOLLOWS Rocklin ACROSS the street To the stage office, wh see Arly and Tala sitting on their horses apparently wait for Rocklin. A third horse is standing by with Rocklin's  saddle on it. Rocklin, upon reaching the front of the stage office, pau a moment, to look over the horse carrying his saddle --  glances up to Arly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be right with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes into the stage of office, as we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LONG SHOT -- as Rocklin, Arly and Juan canter along a dir road over open country with the mountain ranges in the  distance. CAMERA PANS to show a buggy on the road ahead, approachin wooded dell where the road divides.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of the buggy, showing Miss Martin riding in front, beside Shorty Davis, who is driving, and Clara with her back to driver, facing the oncoming trio. Miss Martin hears the s of the approaching horses, and looks over her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arly, Juan and Rocklin, with Miss Martin in F.g. The latt scowls and looks quickly to her front as the riders draw  level with the buggy, Rocklin coining to the right, along Clara.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good afternoon, Mr. Rocklin. (looking at the sky) Lovely day, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reckon it is pretty nice. So you're  moving in on the "K.C." eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hesitating and  throwing a look toward  Miss Martin) We-el, not exactly moving in. You  see...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: with Miss Martin in f.g. and SHOOTING OVER her shoulder t include Clara and Rocklin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (acidly, locking  straight ahead) Do you have to discuss our private  affairs with every rag-tag-and-bobtail  cow-person we meet, Clara?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a low voice) Auntie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry if I butted in, ma'am. Jest  passing the time o'day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can do very well without it --  thank you. (with a look over her  shoulder) And you're keeping your lady friend  waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin looks quickly in the same direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: from Rocklin's ANGLE, with Arly and Juan at the fork in t road. They are looking back towards the buggy which has t the lower road to the right of the copse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: with Arly and Juan in f.g. and the buggy in the distance. Rocklin raises his hat to the women in the buggy and cant back to Arly, who has been watching with a peculiar  expression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coldly) I thought maybe you'd changed your  mind again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cheerfully) Nope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at him angrily for a second as if about to say  something sarcastic. Then, repressing herself, she wheels her horse and canters off along the side of the copse. Ro throws an amused glance, at Juan, who has been watching w an enigmatic expression. He returns Rocklin's look with a stern, menacing frown. Then, with a gentle flick of the r he urges his horse after Arly. Completely baffled, Rockli scratches his head for a second, then follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT -- as the three canter up the driveway to a sma looking ranch house. Arly dismounts and throws her reins Juan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over her shoulder to  Rocklin) Juan'll show you the bunkhouse. I'll  talk to you about your duties in the  morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before Rocklin can speak, she runs quickly up the steps o the verandah and disappears into the house. Leading Arly' Horse, Juan moves out of shot to the left of the ranch ho and Rocklin follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT -- as Juan comes into shot leading the mare,  followed by Rocklin. They both dismount and begin to off- saddle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How far is the line-camp at Table- Top?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty-five -- thirty mile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm moving out there first thing in  the morning. (as Juan turns and  stares) Boss' orders. Care to show me the  way?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a moment's pause. Then, what almost amounts to a smile of relief, crosses Juan's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will show you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LONG SHOT -- as Rocklin and Juan ride out from the ranch  through the early morning mist and turn off in the direct of the distant line of mountains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LONG SHOT -- as the two leave the open country and enter mouth of a steep and narrow gorge at the foot of the moun range.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Juan pulls up and dismounts, followed by Rocklin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing ahead) The trail is straight ahead. You  will find the cabin at the top. (turning back to his  horse) Adios, Senor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (challenging, but  perfectly friendly) Senor Romerez, it appears that you  do not like me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a second Juan does not reply. Then, as he speaks, he  takes a tobacco pouch from his pocket. Rocklin, his mind other things, does not take particular notice of the pouc but we cannot help notice the pouch ornament -- a steer's head of hammered silver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (during the above  business) Senor, that is true. I do not like  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (extending the pouch) Permit that I offer you a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin shakes his head. Juan, having spilled tobacco in paper, now puts away the pouch and rolls his own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is not your fault that your shadow  is black. But you will only bring  unhappiness to my senorita. I do not  blame you, but I fear I must hate  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns abruptly and mounts the waiting horse; then look down from the saddle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adios, Senor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rides quickly out of the shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT -- as Rocklin forces his horse up the last few  feet of the steep trail at the top of the canyon, and pul up at the top of the rise with a look of amazement.

dialogues.speaker: FROM ROCKLIN'S ANGLE
dialogues.text: A rich meadow stretches ahead with a stream running throu it, and a cabin at the far end. Steep escarpments surroun the lush meadow land, making an idyllic scene. As Rocklin comes slowly into shot with the same look of startled  appreciation on his face and begins to move toward the ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LONG SHOT -- of Juan, as he canters across open country t the ranch. CAMERA PANS to include the road from Santa Inez along whi approaches a smallish freight wagon, pulled by two horses As the driver sees Juan and waves his whip, the Mexican  swerves from his course and canters toward the wagon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: wagon, which we now see is being driven by Dave. On the s of the wagon is written: TRANSPORT & GENERAL FREIGHTA Pap Fossler and Sons. Juan canters into shot and pulls up alongside the wagon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hiya there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buenos dias, Senor Dave. (looking at name on  wagon) You have found new employer, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Haulin' freight for ole Pap  Fossler. Got a letter here for that  crazy galoot, Rocklin. (with a little Wink) From the little Caldwell girl. Seems  mighty took up about sumpin'. Made  me promise to deliver it personal. (indicates letter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Senor Rocklin is not here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lordy -- he ain't quit already...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes head) I have just accompany him to Table- Top.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shelley, a Negro servant of the Harolday household, is  discovered sweeping the front porch. Behind him we see Cl open the door -- peer furtively out -- then cross the por to its edge when he looks o.s. as though searching for  someone. Shelley, meantime, has noticed Clint, but goes right on w his sweeping. His only reaction is a disparaging glance o his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning to Shelley) Have you seen Arly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, suh, Ah didn't see Miss Arly  today, but Ah seed her las' night,  and she shore was mad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To emphasize his point, Shelley puckers his mouth in a  whistle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plenty mad!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clint's face tightens as he anticipates what is in store him. Over the scene comes the gradually increasing sound a feminine voice, gayly humming the notes of a popular tu of the period. Clint's strained features relax in a can-t be-Arly expression, while Shelley stops dead in the middl of a sweep, and now both stare incredulously, o.s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From their ANGLE we first see only the corner of the hous while the owner of the voice approaches from the other si Now Arly comes into view, entirely oblivious of Clint and Shelley watching her. She seems more attractive, in a fem way, this morning. It may be the skirt and blouse she is  wearing. Then again it may be the flower she is, even now adjusting in her hair. The presence of the two men sudden startles her. The song ends abruptly, while her hands fal quickly away from the flower.

dialogues.speaker: ARLY
dialogues.text: As Arly moves toward the porch, Shelley snaps back to lif and resumes sweeping -- but furiously. Clint regards the  girl in the vague manner of the puzzled gent he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not too definitely) 'Mornin', Arly --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arly is coming toward Clint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleasantly) 'Mornin', Clint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She steps close to Clint, and he slowly backs up a step, he does not know she came up to him merely to pick up her jacket lying on the ground near the step.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as Arly leans down  to pick up the jacket) You must be feeling pretty good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arly straightens up with the jacket in her hand, and the  corner of her mouth curls in a faint smile. She turns now and starts along the walk, and takes only a few steps whe Clint comes to her side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he joins Arly) Say, Arly -- about that poker game,  night before last, I ---

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tossing it off) Forget it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (did he hear correctly) Forget it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arly pays no attention to Clint. She is looking o.s. and  stops walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tala, on his horse, as seen by Arly. Over the scene comes Arly's voice calling from a distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling) Tala.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tala reacts to the call by heading his horse at a slightl different angle.

dialogues.speaker: ARLY AND CLINT
dialogues.text: Arly is looking o.s. toward Tala. Clint is now eyeing his sister up and down quite openly. She turns her head now a catches Clint looking her over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a stilted pause) Well --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a perplexed  smile) What is this? --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A gesture of his hand indicates the way Arly has gotten  herself up. That quick, Arly's hand goes to the flower in her hair. And, that quick, she guiltily withdraws it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bravely nonchalant) What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do I mean? --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before he can explain, Tala pulls up in his horse and we  hear his voice over the scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Arliete.

dialogues.speaker: ARLY, TALA AND CLINT
dialogues.text: Tala sitting astride his horse smiles down at the girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Tala.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have make yourself very pretty  today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arly is jolted by Tala's innocent remark, and she can't h giving Clint a little side glance in the way of reaction. Clint has not missed Tala's crack nor Arly's glance, and  when she gives it to him he says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleasantly) See what I mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tosses her an altogether knowing look now, and leaves, going up the walk toward the house. Arly turns to Tala.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have my horse saddled and sent around  right away -- will you? (then as a casual  afterthought) You can have that Rocklin bring it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She glances over her shoulder toward Clint going up the w And then, looking back to Tala, finds he hasn't moved, bu remains smiling down at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (easily) Rocklin is not here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (breathlessly) He quit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has gone to the line camp at Table  Top.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was Mr. Harolday's orders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arly looks away. Her eyes stare blankly into space as she struggles with the mixed emotions of anger and disappoint Tala, aware of her plight, slowly dismounts and comes to girl's side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a fatherly manner) Why do you make your heart heavy  with thoughts of him, little one. --  He is not for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bitterly) Be quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has made the choice, Arliete.  With your own eyes you saw it  yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impatiently) Oh --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And she, too, has opened her heart  to him -- Already she has summoned  him to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (this turns her around) What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave -- of the white beard -- carries  a letter to Rocklin -- It is from  her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have just now met Dave, and he  tell me. -- So now he rides to Table  Top.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arly is quiet a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little one you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly, as she starts  for the house) Oh, leave me alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: entrance to ranch. Entering the driveway from the directi of Santa Inez, comes Harolday, still looking the distingu citizen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Julio -- morning Arly. (to Julio as he  dismounts) Fetch my briefcase -- it's on my  desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julio exits.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLDAY TURNS HIS ATTENTION TO ARLY WHO
dialogues.text: still smarting under the disappointment about Rocklin, se lost in thought. After regarding her a moment Harolday sp

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like we're going to get that  land we've been wanting along the  river bottom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arly turns her eyes on Harolday, who continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't tell you -- but I bought  the mortgage on the Hardman ranch,  and it's due today -- On my way over  there now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arly's eyes burn as she tosses her head slightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you send that Rocklin to Table- Top?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (furiously) Well, let's get things straight.  This place was my mother's -- now  it's mine and Clint's -- It's true  you've been helping out -- but the  way things are going we'll soon be  able to pay you back every penny we  owe. Meanwhile, I'm running this  outfit and I expect to give the  orders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You generally do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did you send Rocklin up to Table- Top?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It seemed to me a good idea -- what  with all this rustling going on --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who'd ever try driving cattle over  Table-Top? -- Unless they were crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coldly) I don't agree with you. In any case --  if you must have it -- I'd no  intention of engaging a man at  foreman's wages just to gratify the  whims of a jealous woman!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dangerously) You take care what you're saying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very controlled) It's you should take care, my dear.  I'm afraid there's one man you can't  rawhide into jumping the way you  want. You've made a fool of yourself  over him once. Better watch out you  don't do it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns abruptly and walks off the verandah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Harolday comes from the verandah to his horse. Juan is standing there with the briefcase which Harolday takes wi a yank, mounts his horse and rides out. The CAMERA MOVES IN CLOSE on Arly, who stands in furious  silence watching Harolday ride away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old Dave is jogging along in his wagon. A rumble of thund echoes through the canyon. Dave reacts with a look toward the sky.

dialogues.speaker: SHOT
dialogues.text: of storm clouds gathering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A night shot of the mountain road near Table-Top. It is a wooded section of the plateau, and occasional flashes of  lightning illuminate the big trees skirting the road. Dav in his wagon, looms out of the b.g., and as he nears the  camera we hear him urging the team through the downpour. he passes and continues hurriedly on his way, we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT on a soiled and wrinkled envelope lying on a t It is addressed to: Mr. Rocklin c/o Santee Ranch

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA PULLS BACK and Rocklin is revealed at the tabl looking down at the letter. His hat is tipped back on his head, and his sleeves are rolled up. He is mixing dough i bowl sitting on the table near the letter, and his hands all gooey. Dave is discovered in front of the fireplace w his outer shirt and socks are drying. It is dark outside, but the storm has abated. Rocklin goes to a shelf near th fireplace to get a pan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (during the above) Durn funny -- that storm quittin'  just about the time I get here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No funnier than you sloggin' through  it, just to deliver a letter from a  woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disgustedly) Reckon I'm gettin' to be more of a  fool the older I get.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave watches Rocklin at the table shaping the dough for  biscuits and putting it in the pan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When are we gonna get around to  readin' it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin cannot help smiling a bit at the way Dave include himself in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thought I'd wait till mornin' --  might be bad news an' I wouldn't be  able to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave screws up his face in utter disgust and turns his  attention to his drying clothes. Rocklin, meanwhile, takes a flour sack from the table, wi the dough from his hands and picks up the letter. He goes over to the fireplace, opening the letter the while, and  sits on the bench. Dave, seeing this, edges discreetly ar in back of Rocklin in order to see over his shoulder. The letter open, Rocklin takes out a roll of bills along  with the folded message. He lays the envelope on the benc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmmm -- dineroo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin places the money in his shirt pocket for the mome and opens the folded message. LETTER. It begins with the usual Dear Mr. Rocklin. Rocklin's voice is heard over the insert as he reads from here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading) Forgive me if this letter is a trifle  incoherent, but I am terribly worried  and unhappy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who wouldn't be -- livin' with that  ole screech owl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continues to read) I am desperately in need of help and  advice from someone whom I feel I  can trust, and I am appealing to  you, because I regard you in the  same way my Uncle surely must have.  I heartily dislike and distrust Judge  Garvey --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Huh -- Smart girl --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (going on) But my Aunt seems to have suddenly  revised her opinion of him, and now  wants me to place all my affairs in  the Judge's hands and return east.  Such is certainly not my wish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (significantly) Looks kinda like she's formed an  attachment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin glares up to Dave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly) For the locality, I mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continues reading) I wanted so much to give ranch life  a trial, but fear circumstances are  against me, especially in view of  the recent Indian trouble --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (explosively) Indian trouble -- (in normal tone) Good Lord, they ain't been any Indian  trouble around here in --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (caustically) You want to hear the rest of this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting the inference) Might's well -- come this far.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading) I want to apologize for what took  place this afternoon. And I am  returning the 150, because I feel it  is rightfully yours. You must take  it. Faithfully yours, Clara Caldwell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The letter finished, Rocklin regards it a moment, then sl returns it to the envelope as he gazes thoughtfully into fire. Dave meantime straightens up -- scratches his shaggy top, and turns his attention once more to his drying clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (feeling his socks) Well -- what do you make of it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin continues looking into the fire as he lays the le back on the bench and takes out tobacco to roll a cigaret

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody's sure bustin' to get her  out of there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave sits alongside Rocklin and begins putting on his soc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indian trouble --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a pause) Wonder why the old lady's playin'  along?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sourly) Baaa -- Wimmen -- Who can ever figure  'em? (pause) Got to admit though, I feel a mite  sorry for the young'un -- nice little  tyke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too nice for this country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a slight pause) She's shore a pretty thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin has been mulling things over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't know how I could help her --  even if I wanted to -- I don't know  any thing about this Garvey -- or  Caldwell -- or --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, now -- I could mebbe help you  out some, there -- Fact, I could  tell you somethin' 'bout ole Red  that might be interestin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must have known him pretty well --  What kind of a man was he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin goes to the table and resumes molding biscuits. Dave has his boots on and is putting on his outer shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caldwell? -- The best -- cantankerous  cuss -- but a real cowman, believe  me -- He was a big feller, like  yourself -- Fact, you coulda passed  fer a blood relation, come to think  of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (casually, as he busies  himself with the  biscuits) Was the Judge and Red friends?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (anigmatically) That's what you'd say. Garvey managed  all Red's business. Besides which  they was regular drinkin' pals --  played poker together most nights --  tho' they do say Red got the worst  of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Red was a gambler, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah -- reckon a pretty poor  one, tho' -- still you'd say him and  Garvey was friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a side glance  to Dave) Anything ever happen to make you  think they weren't?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (moves close to Rocklin) Rock -- I'm gonna tell you somethin'  I ain't never told anybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a slight smile) Think you can trust me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave grimaces his confidence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The last time I seen Red was the day  he died --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the pause Rocklin remains silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- 'Twas in town -- he jus' come out  of the stage office. Tried to book  passage to Garden City but couldn't  on account I had a full load. --  Well, sir, he took me aside and give  me a printed sheet of paper and says,  "Read it." I looked it over and fer  as I could see it was a paper from  one of them Chicago sportin' firms,  tellin' how to manipulate trick  playin' cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marked cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods) Reckon so. -- Seems Red found some  cards and this paper in a coat one  of his friends loaned him one night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whose was it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, now that's just what I asked --  but all he said, was that it belonged  to a good friend. Then he said he  wasn't waitin' fer the next coach,  but was ridin' over to see the  district judge about it alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's when they got him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir -- 'bout a mile or so from  Stan's place. A bullet in the back  an' his pockets empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come you never told this before?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who was there to tell? -- Sheriff  Jackson? -- Him an' Garvey's thick  as thieves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about what's his name -- Harolday? --  He's no friend of the Judge's, is  he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hates his guts -- sure riles him to  see young Clint hangin' onto the  Judge's coattails. All the same, I  jus' decided to keep my mouth shut  and my eyes open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a pause) Even if it was Garvey Red was talkin'  about -- it don't follow that he  killed him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- general opinion is that it was  rustlers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would rustlers take the evidence  Caldwell had with him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin moves away to a large earthen jug holding water a Dave talks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks to me if you get the man who  owned the marked cards, you get the  killer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (drinking) Funny tho' -- first the K.C. foreman --  then Caldwell -- an' now these women.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lordy -- you ain't thinkin' somebody  might try bumpin' them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slowly, to himself) I'm not so sure somebody hasn't tried  already -- (to Dave) Remember, when we stopped to change  horses on the way Over from Garden  City --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shore -- you told me how Jackson and  Clews tried to frame Stan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods) Yeah. Like they wanted to be sure  he'd keep his mouth shut about  something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave sits down on a box sitting against the wall, directl under the large earthen jug of water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And layin' that gun across my skull --  an' offerin' to drive the coach  themselves.

dialogues.speaker: A SECTION OF THE CLEARING
dialogues.text: A dark, mysterious figure on a horse raises his rifle --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods) It was almost as if --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A shot splinters the windowpane and shatters the earthen on the shelf directly above Dave's head. The contents pou down on Dave and he topples over. Rocklin meanwhile has w the lantern off the table and ducked. They are both on th floor in the faint glow coming from the fireplace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (going to Dave) You all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (blustering) Will be if I ever get dry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin takes off his hat and puts his finger through two holes drilled by the bullet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lookit that --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good Lord --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin puts the hat aside -- crawls over to his gun belt straps it on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He opens the door cautiously. Then sneaks out, followed b Dave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin and Dave stand close to the cabin, just clear of door, tensely scanning the surrounding darkness. Water can be heard dripping from the cabin roof, and an o hoots in a near-by tree. The sound of neighing horses comes from the direction of corral. Both men re-act.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My team.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almost immediately the neighing is repeated, but this tim from another direction entirely -- and from a distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not your team.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves to the corner of the cabin, followed by Dave.

dialogues.speaker: HORSE IS STOMPING NERVOUSLY
dialogues.text: and now it starts away, galloping through the deep grass the edge of the clearing. Only the lower part of the anim is seen, along with the legs of the rider.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKLIN AND DAVE HEAR THE SOUND OF RETREATING HOOF BEATS
dialogues.text: And they can barely make out their quarry riding hell-ben toward the deep blackness of the trees. Rocklin fires and runs out into the moonlight in the clea Dave close behind. Rocklin halts -- fires again -- and again. Dave fires. The mysterious rider is now swallowed by the night. Dave starts after him again. Looking back, he sees Rockli has not moved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No use -- he's gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mebbe we winged him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts through the wet grass alone. Rocklin turns back toward the cabin.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: He has reached the edge of the clearing where a slight  embankment leads to the level of the trees. He is just  starting up to higher ground when his eyes catch somethin on the embankment, shining in the moonlight. It proves to a tobacco pouch bearing a steer's head of hammered sliver It is dry, so has evidently just been dropped. Dave pocke it, and proceeds warily along the mystery rider's trail.

dialogues.speaker: ROCLKLIN
dialogues.text: He looks back in Dave's direction, and then looking towar the cabin, suddenly stops and tenses.

dialogues.speaker: THE CABIN DOOR IS PARTLY OPEN
dialogues.text: and through it Rocklin can plainly see an indistinct form moving in the faint glow of the dying fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin has reached the entrance unheard, and silently wa the strange figure, its back to him, now headed for the  fireplace with his saddlebag, taken from the bunk. He see the intruder start emptying his saddlebag on the bench in the light of the fire. He sees him suddenly stop and pick something hidden from his view. At that instant, Rocklin slams the door shut. The intruder whirls around. It is Arly -- tense -- and now defiant. The two regard each other like vicious animals in the sam cage. Arly's heart is pounding, but you would never know And now Rocklin, his gun away, starts closing in, slowly but Arly holds her ground -- her eyes never leaving his. When Rocklin reaches Arly, he takes her one hand from beh her back, and slowly forcing it up sees what is obviously Clara's letter in her tightly clenched fist. He tries to  open her hand, and Arly, knowing she lacks the strength t prevent it, suddenly whips out a knife with her free hand But that quick, Rocklin grabs the knife hand, and without any apparent effort, wrenches it free of her grasp and to it across the room, where it lands on the bunk. Arly rela her grip on the letter meanwhile, and Rocklin gets it, an tears it very deliberately, letting the pieces fall at he feet. He turns his back on her now, going over to his hat on th floor. Arly is furious in her helplessness and humiliation. And  Rocklin's smug manner isn't helping any. He picks up his and, glancing at Arly, puts his finger once more through bullet holes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling wryly) Not bad shootin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (right back at him) You think I did that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure -- to draw us away from here. (looks at his hat) You know, you cut it mighty close --  Good thing I ain't got brains enough  to fill it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin puts his hat on. He sees Arly looking down at the torn letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suppressing smile) Too bad you had to come 'way up here  through that storm for nothin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (affectedly) I haven't minded a bit -- (harshly) -- because I came up to fire you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh -- (nods) I see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin goes toward the bunk with his saddlebag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out of here -- get off the Santee  and don't ever come back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mind if I wait for Dave? He ought to  be along any minute -- Be funny if  he winged that shadow of yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you mean Juan -- you're loco.  He's not even up here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mildly surprised) You came up alone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (half believing her) Then who was that we took out after?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man who shot at you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin sits on the bunk and casually picks up Arly's kni

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who was he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean you won't tell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean I don't know -- Why should I  lie to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That last from Arly brings a kind of smile to Rocklin's f a smile that says in effect -- "Are you kidding?" He gets from the bunk to go to the door, and finding himself stil holding Arly's knife, throws it back to her in a seemingl casual manner. It passes too close to Arly for comfort an Rocklin just opening the door, gets the knife right back that close to his ear he feels the breeze. He looks at it quivering in the door. Then, moving to Arly in what could construed as a threatening manner, he takes her in his ar and kisses her. Arly is caught completely unaware. Rockli action disarms her. But it is, after all, what she really wants, so before the kiss ends, Arly's arms slowly entwin themselves around Rocklin's neck. In the middle of the ki Rocklin gently but forcefully takes her arms from around neck and puts her from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess you forgot -- you jes' fired  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes to the bunk -- picks up his saddlebag, coat, etc. and starts for the door. Arly has been silently watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning near the  open door) So long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave's voice is heard just outside the cabin door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Rock --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave now rushes through the door, puffing and excited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- He got away -- but guess what, I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sees Arly and pulls up abruptly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slowly to Dave) You guess --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin gives Arly a disparaging side glance and starts o

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Dave, who is trying  to figure things out) Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin is headed for the corral as Dave catches up to hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glancing back to the  cabin) Fer a man who's got a despise fer  wimmin, you sure do get all snaggled  up with 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arly, her back to us, is standing in the open doorway wat the two headed for the corral. Her mood is evidenced by the manner in which she suddenly slams shut the door. As she turns and leans against it, w see tears in her eyes, and hear suppressed sobs. Her eyes light on the bits of torn letter, and presently we see he face set itself grimly, and now she walks toward the fire and, passing the torn bite of paper, kicks at them viciou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LONG SHOT -- of Rocklin as he comes riding into town. As nears the corner where the stage and Harolday's office is situated, the CAMERA MOVES IN, getting Rocklin and one of the Harolday employees repairing the wooden sidewalk near the hitching rail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he dismounts) You work for Harolday?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's one of his horses -- I'll  pick up my saddle later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He enters the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PANNING SHOT on Harolday as he sits at the desk working o ledger. The sound of a door opening is heard. Harolday lo up casually as if expecting a customer, then suddenly gap CAMERA PANS to include doorway in which stands Rocklin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Howdy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frowning) I thought I sent you up to Table- Top.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slowly) What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking off his hat) Well, this, for one thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pokes a finger through the hole in the crown. Harolday eyes narrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a little pause) I told you you'd regret letting that  rat Clews off so easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin looks at him with a queer expression without repl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter? Don't you think  it was him, then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slowly) I been figgerin'. Don't seem  reasonable Clews was in condition to  take that sort of chance alone...  Besides -- how could he have known I  was up there -- that soon. And --  George Clews ain't the only one I've  run contrariwise to in this town.  There's that Mexican, for instance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He as good as told me yesterday that  him and me was due for a run-in one  of those days. (suddenly nodding  toward window) And then there's him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harolday looks sharply toward the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT from office window. Clint is hurrying across fr the direction of the Sun-Up Saloon toward the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PANNING SHOT on Clint as he enters from street and crosse to the door of Harolday's office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT on door of inner office with Harolday at desk i f.g. As the door opens it conceals Rocklin from Clint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (excitedly) I just heard that -- that Rocklin  was -- (sees Rocklin)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slowly) Was what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (subdued) Was shot at last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very calm) Mr. Rocklin was just telling me all  about it. (significantly) Any idea who might have done it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clint looks quickly at Harolday and back at Rocklin with  frightened eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin makes no reply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ain't trying to pin it on me? (his courage returning) 'Cause if you are, you're in for a  big disappointment. I was over at  the Sun-Up playing poker with the  Judge and the rest of the boys till  early morning. If you don't believe  me, ask for yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a pause) All right. I believe you. But that  don't mean you couldn't tell a thing  or two as would help -- if you wanted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very nervous again) What d'you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharply) Yes. What sort of thing would Clint  here know about, that would help  identify the man who tried to kill  you last night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This for one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls out the tobacco pouch which Dave found at Table- Top.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ever seen it before?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clint as he stares wide-eyed at the pouch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: group, with Rocklin and Harolday both watching Clint inte

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (harshly) Well, go on -- speak up. Did you  ever see it before?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (avoiding Harolday's  eye) No. Course I didn't (suddenly raging at  Rocklin) Quit riding me! I don't know nothin'  about it I tell you. Jest because I  had a run-in with you over a game o'  cards, that don't mean I'd sneak up  on you in the dark and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin's disdainful smile takes the speech out of Clint, who just sort of runs out of words. Rocklin hesitates for second then moves toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harolday and Clint are at window looking past camera towa the street. They see Rocklin carrying his saddle, walking toward the Sun-Up. Shorty Davis hails Rocklin, says somet to him and points to the Sun-Up. Rocklin leaves, walking  faster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frowning deeply) He means trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns from camera toward the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still at window) Aw, what do I care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning on him with  cold fury) Listen, I never did have much use  for you. You're a poor specimen at  the best; but as a would-be bad man  you're nothing but a laughing stock.  Why, the way you lied about that  pouch just now wouldn't have deceived  a six-year old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (harshly) All right, let it go at that. But I  got myself to think of. It wouldn't  suit me at all just now to have you  shown up in public for what you are  by that trouble-shootin' cowhand. My  advice to you is to get out of the  district and stay out. (taking a key from  his vest pocket) You'll find some money in the safe  at the ranch. Take what you need and  put the key in the desk drawer. Now  get.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin comes down the hall carrying his saddle and looki at the room numbers. As he nears the f.g. he locates the  room he is looking for (it is a room facing toward the re of the Sun-Up). He knocks. Almost immediately the door op and Clara stands there -- flushed and embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Mr. Rocklin --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the room in which Clara has arranged to meet Rock who later takes it as his own. SHOT at door as Rocklin steps into the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so glad I've found you -- I was  on my way to the Santee and learned  you were in town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (putting his saddle,  etc., aside) Just got in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel perfectly awful, running after  you like this, but --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got trouble, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My aunt found out I wrote you and  made a terrible scene --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You haven't signed everything over  to that Garvey, have you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- and because I refused, Auntie  said she would sign an affidavit  that I'm still underage, and then,  as my guardian she can do what she  likes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got anything to prove you're not  underage?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a slight pause) No -- but Mr. Garvey has a letter  that would prove it. My aunt wrote  it before we came out here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: S'pose we could get it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'd never give it to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (starts for door) Wait here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a slight start  toward Rocklin) Oh, please -- you -- (she hesitates, not  quite sure what to  say) You won't go getting yourself in  trouble -- I -- I'd rather give up  everything -- I mean --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin notes her confusion. He regards her with a slight sympathetic smile. Then opens the door and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT -- a letter written in a bold feminine hand. I reads:

dialogues.speaker: DEAR MR. GARVEY
dialogues.text: In answer to your letter of the 25th, kindly be advised t my niece, Clara Caldwell, became of age January 11th of t year. And, although I am no longer her legal guardian, it behooves me, as her nearest kin, to show continued intere in her affairs -- The CAMERA HOLDS LONG ENOUGH for the letter to be read. A now the letter begins to be consumed in a flame as the CA PULLS BACK showing the burning letter in Judge Garvey's h He is standing over the potbellied stove in his office, a Miss Martin is close to him watching the letter burn. Gar finally lets it fall from his fingers onto the top of the stove. He lifts the lid, lets the remains fall inside, an smiles to Miss Martin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That takes care of that -- (crosses to his desk) Now, I'll draw up an affidavit right  away and everything will be taken  care of as we want it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not too enthusiastic) I certainly hope so -- it's not myself  I'm concerned about --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting out the papers) -- Of course not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't say I'm very happy about  doing this -- I only hope it works  out for the best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the better choice of two evils --  now let's see -- (begins to write) I, Elizabeth -- (looks at Miss Martin) It is Elizabeth, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Elizabeth Martin, of Danvers,  Massachusetts, do hereby --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens and Rocklin enters. Miss Martin, who has b pacing nervously, stops in her tracks. Garvey, taken  completely by surprise, feigns an affected casualness. Ro eyes them both suspiciously as he slowly closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leaning back in his  chair) Well, Mr. Rocklin, this is indeed a  surprise. Didn't expect to see you  so soon. I understood you were riding  for the Santee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coldly) That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is quite obvious to Garvey that Rocklin is here on  business. He turns to Miss Martin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Miss Martin) Perhaps you'd better come back later --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Martin is in accord with that suggestion, and after  giving Rocklin the frigid eye, flounces out, slamming the door. Garvey shakes his head, wipes his brow, and is returning his desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHOT -- door to Garvey's office. Miss Martin has her ear  glued to the panels. Over scene comes Rocklin's voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I came for that letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Martin reacts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHOT -- Garvey and Rocklin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calmly) Did you say letter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right -- the one Miss  Caldwell's aunt wrote from out east  sayin' she was of age. Remember?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- I'm afraid I don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHOT -- door. Miss Martin reacts with nod of satisfaction and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin goes to the filing cabinet where he opens the dra marked "C." As he fingers through the papers, Garvey sits back in his chair, watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is your interest in this letter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My only interest is getting' it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You realize what this is, don't you? --  Robbing -- armed robbery at that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin pulls open the "M" drawer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I warn you, you're in for a  disappointment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not finding the letter in the "M" drawer, Rocklin goes to the desk and pulls the handle of one of the drawers. It i locked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Open up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (has had about enough) Listens, you -- (suddenly controls  himself) There's nothing in there that'd  interest you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grimly) I'd like to make up my own mind about  that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (forces a chuckle) All right -- I'll open it -- just to  convince you I'm not hiding any  letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Garvey unlocks the drawer and opens it. It is found to co nothing but two brand new decks of playing cards. The UNOPENED DECKS OF CARDS. BACK TO SCENE. Garvey seems a little too anxious to close the drawer, and before he can do so, Rocklin has one hand inside. Garvey, checked for a second, looks up at Rocklin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the idea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin slowly withdraws his hand, holding one of the dec

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These cards --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (attempting to bluff  it out) Anything wrong in a man having cards  in his possession?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Depends on what kind they are --  'specially when they're under lock  and key.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two regard each other silently a moment. Now Rocklin  casually slips the deck he holds into his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (too politely) You're taking those, I presume.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes a step away. Garvey turns him by touching his ar

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (has had almost enough) Now, you look here --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (soberly) You're the one who better start  lookin' -- lookin' for a way out for  killin' Red Caldwell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (blanches) Caldwell --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (takes up one of the  decks of cards) He found out about these -- and you  went and killed him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with an affected  smile and unnatural  calmness) And you believe a story like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will until I hear a better one. (puts deck he holds,  in his pocket) I'll just take this along -- the  district judge at Garden City should  be mighty interested.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts around the desk toward the door. From the corne of his eye he catches Garvey reaching for a gun in the mi drawer. Before he can raise it, Rocklin is on him with a  blow that sends Garvey reeling back toward the stove. Rocklin starts for the door again, and just misses being  struck by a chair which Garvey hurls with vicious fury. T chair crashes against a window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sound of breaking glass attracts the attention of pas by, as well as Miss Martin seated in her surrey with Samm the K.C. China-boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two are now fighting in earnest.

dialogues.speaker: VARIOUS FLASHES
dialogues.text: of the fight, intercut with townspeople gathering outside

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave pulls up in his wagon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is pretty well wrecked. Rocklin has Garvey just about  done in. He gives him one final Sunday punch and Garvey g down and stays down. At that moment, Dave and Pap Fossler enter followed by other curious natives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say -- looks like you two been  disagreein' 'bout somethin' -- (to Fossler, who has  gone over to Garvey) He ain't daid, is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not permanently, I don't reckon. --  What happened, anyways?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Rocklin) You musta found out somethin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a wink to Dave) I reckon the Judge did, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They exit, and almost immediately Miss Martin enters, and after gaping in horror at the appearance of the place, se the Judge, who, having regained consciousness, bestirs hi on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, dear -- dear -- are you hurt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting up painfully) Get out of my way --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Garvey, on his feet now, makes for the door leading to hi living quarters at the back of the office. Miss Martin fo him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (haughtily) Now don't you use that tone of voice  to me -- (going through doorway) I'll have you understand I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sees the bed and shrieks upon realizing where she is, and backs out quickly, almost catching the door which Gar slams in her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin and Dave as they walk from Garvey's office. Dave a time hopping along against Rocklin's strides.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Find out who owns that tobaccy  pouch yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (staring straight  ahead) No -- but get hold of Clint Harolday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clint -- Is he in on it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't say for sure -- Bring him to  the Sun-Up, and don't take no for an  answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave leaves and exits from shot in the direction of the s office. Rocklin goes off toward the Sun-Up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PANNING SHOT. Juan is lounging against the corner of the  building, soberly watching Rocklin's approach. As Rocklin comes into the scene he spots Juan, and stops a moment as though deciding whether or not to question him. During th Juan casually takes his ornamental tobacco pouch from his pocket and begins to roll a cigarette. The CAMERA PANS Rocklin to the side of the building and u the outer stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin comes through the door and down the hall. He reac his room, and is about to open the door when he hears a  familiar voice inside. He listens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- So now you know the truth. And if  you think you can steal him away  from me, you're welcome to try it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin frowns and enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin steps into the room, holding the door partly open he focuses his attention on Arly. Clara, who has been sit in the rocker near the window, gets up and is the first t speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (anxiously) Did you get it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- but I don't think it's gonna  matter much -- you go on back to the  K.C. and I'll be out in the mornin'  and take you with me to Garden City  to see the district judge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I hate putting you to that  trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No trouble at all -- I'm going anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (casually) You look like you've been fighting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (soberly) What are you doin' here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just telling Miss Caldwell  about -- well -- you and me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (his eyes narrowing) What about, you an' me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sensing the static  in the atmosphere) I think I'd better be going...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning quickly from  Arly) Just a minute -- (glances at Arly) What all has she been tellin' you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (embarrassed) Oh -- oh, really I'd rather not --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Go ahead, tell him -- (looks at Rocklin and  goes on defiantly) -- and I dare him to deny it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deny what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That she was with you last night at  the cabin in the mountains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- why should I deny it?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly) And didn't you make love to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (this is getting a  bit thick for him) Make love to you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (forcing her point) You didn't kiss me -- I suppose?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you expect me to deny that, too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles at Clara) You see?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Clara) Now, maybe you ought to hear what  I've got to say --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clara is terribly hurt, but struggles to be grown-up abou it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please -- you needn't explain. After  all, it really isn't any of my  business, is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in the pause he looks  at Arly) You little --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly) That's it -- start swearin'-- (to Clara) Just like a man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If there wasn't a lady here, I'd do  more to you than swear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know how I can ever thank  you for trying to help me. I do  appreciate it ever so much -- (to Arly) Don't think too harshly of me, will  you -- I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clara can say no more without breaking. So she turns away quickly and hurries out the door. Rocklin does a slow bur as he glares at Arly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sincerely -- after a  pause) She's lovely, isn't she? -- So sweet --  honest, and helpless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocklin makes no reply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pity you didn't fall in love with  her, instead of me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arly is being ridiculous now. He ignores her remarks and  concentrates his attention on one of his hands -- he may  have sprained it slightly in the fight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You might's well know right now that  you or no woman is ever goin' to get  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be so sure -- I don't think  I'm doin' so badly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know there ain't a dirty trick you  wouldn't play to get what you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) I always get what I want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
